article:
Wangaratta Football Club
=====================

The Wangaratta Football Club, also known as the Wangaratta Magpies, is an Australian rules football club based in Wangaratta, Victoria. The club was founded in 1871 and has a rich history in the Ovens and Murray Football League (OMFL). The Magpies have a strong following in the region and have produced several talented footballers who have gone on to play in the Victorian Football League (VFL) and Australian Football League (AFL).

Club History
------------

### Early Years (1871-1900)

The Wangaratta Football Club was established in 1871, making it one of the oldest football clubs in Victoria. In the early years, the club played in various local competitions, including the Wangaratta District Football Association. The Magpies experienced some success during this period, winning several local premierships.

### Ovens and Murray Football League (1901-1945)

In 1901, the Wangaratta Football Club joined the Ovens and Murray Football League (OMFL), which was established in 1893. The Magpies quickly established themselves as a competitive team in the league, winning their first OMFL premiership in 1905. The club went on to win several more premierships in the following decades, including a hat-trick of flags from 1928 to 1930.

### Post-War Era (1946-1970)

Following World War II, the Wangaratta Football Club continued to compete in the OMFL. The Magpies experienced some success during this period, winning premierships in 1948 and 1958. The club also produced several talented players who went on to play in the VFL, including Ron Clegg and Barry Connolly.

### Modern Era (1971-Present)

In the 1970s and 1980s, the Wangaratta Football Club continued to compete in the OMFL, winning premierships in 1973 and 1983. The club also produced several players who went on to play in the VFL and AFL, including Mark Hannebery and Brett Allison. In recent years, the Magpies have continued to be a competitive team in the OMFL, winning premierships in 2007 and 2017.

2023 Cricket World Cup

The 2023 Cricket World Cup is the 13th edition of the Cricket World Cup, a quadrennial international cricket tournament contested by national teams from the International Cricket Council (ICC). The tournament is scheduled to take place in India from October 5 to November 19, 2023. The 2023 World Cup will feature 10 teams, with the top four teams qualifying for the semi-finals.

#Background

The 2023 Cricket World Cup was originally scheduled to take place in 2023, but due to the COVID-19 pandemic, the ICC postponed the tournament to 2023. The tournament will be the first ICC Cricket World Cup to be held entirely in India, with the country hosting the event for the first time since 2011. The 2023 World Cup will also be the first tournament to feature a new format, with the top four teams qualifying for the semi-finals.

#Qualification

The qualification process for the 2023 Cricket World Cup was based on the ICC ODI rankings, with the top seven teams qualifying automatically. The remaining three teams qualified through the ICC ODI Championship, which took place from 2015 to 2020. The teams that qualified for the tournament are:

article:
Finland–NATO relations refer to the bilateral relations between Finland and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), as well as Finland's relations with other NATO member states. Finland's relationship with NATO has undergone significant changes throughout the years, from a policy of neutrality during the Cold War to its current status as a NATO member state.

# History

## Background: Finnish neutrality at the end of World War II

Finland declared its independence from Russia in 1917 and fought two wars against the Soviet Union in 1939-1940 (the Winter War) and 1941-1944 (the Continuation War). The end of World War II led to Finland signing the Paris Peace Treaty in 1947, which imposed significant territorial losses and limited its military capabilities. Finland's foreign policy during the Cold War era was characterized by a desire to maintain its sovereignty and avoid entanglement in the conflict between the Eastern and Western Blocs. This policy of neutrality was enshrined in the Paasikivi-Kekkonen doctrine, named after Finnish Presidents Juho Kusti Paasikivi and Urho Kekkonen, who played key roles in shaping the country's foreign policy during this period.

## 1949–2023: Pre-membership relations

### 1949–1991: Finnish neutrality during the Cold War

Finland maintained its policy of neutrality throughout the Cold War, avoiding membership in any military alliance. However, Finland did participate in various international organizations, such as the United Nations, and engaged in diplomatic relations with countries from both the Eastern and Western Blocs. In 1948, Finland signed the YYA Treaty ( Treaty of Friendship, Cooperation, and Mutual Assistance) with the Soviet Union, which included provisions for mutual defense in the event of an attack. While this treaty did not constitute a formal alliance, it did create a framework for cooperation between the two countries.

### 1991–1995: Immediate aftermath of the Cold War

The collapse of the Soviet Union in 1991 marked a significant turning point in Finland's foreign policy. The YYA Treaty was officially terminated in 1992, and Finland began to reorient its foreign policy towards Western Europe and the United States. In 1992, Finland joined the European Union's predecessor, the European Economic Community (EEC), and later became a full member of the European Union in 1995.

### 1995–2022: Shift from non-alignment within the European Union

During the 1990s and early 2000s, Finland began to participate in various NATO-led operations, such as the Kosovo Force (KFOR) and the International Security Assistance Force (ISAF) in Afghanistan. While Finland maintained its policy of non-alignment, it did develop closer ties with NATO through the Partnership for Peace (PfP) program, which was established in 1994. Finland also participated in various EU-led crises management operations, such as the EUFOR Althea mission in Bosnia and Herzegovina.

### 2022–2023: Accession process following the Russian invasion of Ukraine

#### February – May 2022: Initial response to the invasion

Russia's invasion of Ukraine in February 2022 marked a significant turning point in Finland's relations with NATO. Finland's government, led by Prime Minister Sanna Marin, condemned the invasion and announced a significant increase in defense spending. Finland also participated in various international efforts to support Ukraine, including the provision of humanitarian aid and military assistance.

#### May – June 2022: Declaration of intent, application

On May 15, 2022, Finland's President Sauli Niinistö and Prime Minister Sanna Marin announced that the country would seek NATO membership. This decision was made in response to the changed security environment in Europe and the need for Finland to strengthen its defense capabilities. Finland's parliament, the Eduskunta, approved the decision on May 17, 2022, with a vote of 188 in favor and 8 against. Finland officially submitted its membership application to NATO on May 18, 2022.

#### June 2022 – April 2023: Ratification

Finland's accession process was formally launched on June 29, 2022, when NATO's North Atlantic Council (NAC) invited Finland to join the alliance. The accession talks were completed on July 4, 2022, and the Accession Protocol was signed on July 5, 2022. The ratification process was completed on April 4, 2023, when Turkey's parliament, the Grand National Assembly, approved Finland's accession. Finland officially became a NATO member state on April 4, 2023.

## 2023–present: Finnish membership in NATO

Finland's membership in NATO marks a significant turning point in the country's foreign and security policy. As a NATO member state, Finland is committed to contributing to the alliance's collective defense efforts and participating in NATO-led operations. Finland's membership is also expected to strengthen the country's defense capabilities and enhance its security cooperation with other NATO member states.

# Finland's foreign relations with other NATO member states

Finland's relations with other NATO member states are an important aspect of its membership in the alliance. Finland has developed close ties with various NATO member states, including the United States, the United Kingdom, and Germany. Finland has also participated in various NATO-led operations and has contributed to the alliance's collective defense efforts.

Finland's relations with its Nordic neighbors, including Sweden, Norway, and Denmark, are also significant. Finland has developed close ties with these countries through various regional organizations, such as the Nordic Cooperation (NORDEFCO) and the Arctic Council.

article:
The Sandman (TV series)

The Sandman is a fantasy drama television series based on the 1989-1996 comic book series of the same name by Neil Gaiman, Sam Kieth, and Mike Dringenberg. The show premiered on Netflix on August 5, 2022. Developed by Allan Heinberg, the series follows the story of Dream, also known as Morpheus, one of the seven Endless, a family of powerful beings who personify various aspects of the universe.

#Premise

The Sandman is set in a universe where mythological and supernatural entities exist, and explores the realms of dreams, the afterlife, and the nature of reality. The series follows Dream, who is also known as Morpheus, as he embarks on a journey to reclaim his powers and restore order to the universe after being imprisoned for 70 years. Along the way, he encounters a variety of characters, including other members of his family, mythical creatures, and humans who are affected by his presence.

#Cast

##Main

* Tom Sturridge as Dream/Morpheus: The protagonist of the series, also known as Morpheus, one of the seven Endless. He is the embodiment of dreams and the ruler of the Dreaming.
* Boyd Holbrook as Corinthian: A nightmare created by Dream who serves as his agent in the waking world.
* Patton Oswalt as Matthew the Raven: A raven who serves as Dream's messenger and confidant.
* Vivienne Acheampong as Lucien: Dream's chief librarian and caretaker of the Dreaming.
* Charles Dance as Roderick Burgess: A magician who imprisons Dream for 70 years.
* Jenna Coleman as Johanna Constantine: A 18th-century occult detective who becomes Dream's ally.

##Co-starring

* David Thewlis as John Dee: A magician who seeks to gain ultimate power.
* Kirby Howell-Baptiste as Death: Dream's sister, the personification of death.
* Mason Alexander Park as Desire: Dream's sibling, the personification of desire.
* Donna Preston as Despair: Dream's sibling, the personification of despair.
* Vanesu Samunyai as Rose Walker: A young woman who becomes Dream's ally.

##Recurring

* Gwendoline Christie as Lucifer Morningstar: The ruler of Hell and a member of the heavenly host.
* Mark Hamill as Merv Pumpkinhead: A demon and a servant of Lucifer.
* Stephen Fry as Gilbert: A man who becomes Dream's ally.
* Niamh Walsh as Ethel Cripps: A woman who becomes Dream's ally.

##Guest

* Michael Sheen as Good Omens' Aziraphale: A demon who appears in a cameo role.
* Derek Jacobi as Erasmus Fry: A man who appears in a flashback.

#Episodes

##Season 1 (2022)

The first season of The Sandman premiered on August 5, 2022, and consists of 11 episodes.

1. "Sleep of the Just"
2. "Imperfect Hosts"

10. "Lost Hearts"
11. "Dream of a Thousand Cats/Calliope!"

##Season 2

The second season of The Sandman has been announced, but no release date has been confirmed.

#Production

##Development

###As a film

The Sandman was initially developed as a film, with Roger Avary set to direct and Neil Gaiman serving as an executive producer. However, the project stalled in development hell.

###Transition to television

In 2019, it was announced that The Sandman would be developed as a television series, with Allan Heinberg serving as the showrunner. Neil Gaiman and David S. Goyer were also announced as executive producers.

##Writing

The writing team for The Sandman includes Allan Heinberg, Neil Gaiman, and David S. Goyer, among others. The show's scripts were written in collaboration with the writers and the production team.

##Casting

The casting process for The Sandman was extensive, with the production team seeking to find the right actors to play the complex characters. Tom Sturridge was cast as Dream, with Boyd Holbrook, Patton Oswalt, and Vivienne Acheampong also joining the cast.

##Production design

The production design for The Sandman was led by the production designer, who worked closely with the director and the writers to create the show's visual style.

##Filming

The filming for The Sandman took place in various locations, including the United Kingdom and Canada. The show's cinematographer worked closely with the director to create the show's visual style.

##Post-production

The post-production process for The Sandman involved the editing team, who worked closely with the director and the writers to create the show's final cut.

##Visual effects

The visual effects for The Sandman were created by a team of visual effects artists, who worked closely with the director and the production team to create the show's complex visual effects.

#Music

The music for The Sandman was composed by David Buckley, who worked closely with the director and the production team to create the show's score.

#Release

The Sandman was released on Netflix on August 5, 2022.

##Marketing

The marketing campaign for The Sandman was extensive, with the production team releasing various promotional materials, including trailers and posters.

#Reception

##Audience viewership

The Sandman was viewed by millions of people worldwide, with the show becoming one of the most-watched Netflix series of 2022.

##Critical response

The Sandman received widespread critical acclaim, with many praising the show's visuals, writing, and performances.

##Accolades

The Sandman received several awards and nominations, including a Primetime Emmy Award nomination for Outstanding Special Visual Effects in a Supporting Role.

Nongdā Lāiren Pākhangbā was a king of the Meitei kingdom, which is now part of the Indian state of Manipur. He is known for his significant contributions to the development of the kingdom, particularly in the fields of law and order, art and culture, and medical care. This article provides an overview of his life, reign, and legacy.

#Rise to Power

Nongdā Lāiren Pākhangbā rose to power in the 13th century, a time of great turmoil and conflict in the Meitei kingdom. Pākhangbā's rise to power was facilitated by his military prowess and his ability to build alliances with neighboring tribes. article:
Killing of Ayman al-Zawahiri

The killing of Ayman al-Zawahiri, the second-in-command of the Islamist extremist group al-Qaeda, occurred on July 31, 2022, when he was struck and killed by a drone strike in Kabul, Afghanistan. Al-Zawahiri, an Egyptian physician and theologian, had taken over as leader of al-Qaeda following the death of Osama bin Laden in 2011.

# Background

Ayman al-Zawahiri was born on June 19, 1951, in Giza, Egypt. He studied medicine at Cairo University and later earned a master's degree in surgery from the same institution. Al-Zawahiri became increasingly radicalized in his youth, influenced by the ideology of the Muslim Brotherhood. He eventually joined the Egyptian Islamic Jihad (EIJ), a militant group dedicated to overthrowing the Egyptian government and establishing an Islamic state.

In the 1980s, al-Zawahiri traveled to Afghanistan to participate in the mujahideen resistance against the Soviet occupation. There, he met Osama bin Laden, with whom he formed a close alliance. Following the Soviet withdrawal, al-Zawahiri returned to Egypt, where he continued to advocate for Islamist revolution. In 1998, he merged the EIJ with bin Laden's al-Qaeda organization, becoming the group's second-in-command.

After the 9/11 attacks, al-Zawahiri went into hiding, evading capture by Western intelligence agencies. Following bin Laden's death in 2011, al-Zawahiri took over as leader of al-Qaeda, vowing to continue the group's campaign of global jihad.

# Preparation

The operation to kill Ayman al-Zawahiri was months in the making. U.S. intelligence agencies had been tracking al-Zawahiri's movements, gathering intelligence on his habits and patterns of behavior. In the spring of 2022, the CIA learned that al-Zawahiri had relocated to a safe house in Kabul's Sherpur neighborhood, a upscale district known for its high-security compounds.

U.S. officials reportedly worked closely with Afghan informants and assets to gather more information on al-Zawahiri's location and routine. The CIA also used advanced surveillance technology, including drones and satellite imagery, to monitor the safe house and its surroundings.

As the operation neared, the Biden administration debated whether to conduct a drone strike or a special operations raid. Ultimately, officials decided on a drone strike, citing the risks of civilian casualties and the potential for al-Zawahiri to escape or be warned of an impending raid.

# Operation

On July 31, 2022, at approximately 6:18 a.m. local time, a CIA-operated drone launched two Hellfire missiles at the safe house in Sherpur. The missiles struck the balcony of the building, where al-Zawahiri was standing. The blast killed al-Zawahiri instantly, along with several other individuals, including a woman and a child.

The U.S. military confirmed the strike in a statement, saying that al-Zawahiri had been killed in a "counterterrorism operation" in Kabul. The statement did not provide further details on the operation or the methods used to conduct the strike.

# Aftermath

The killing of Ayman al-Zawahiri sparked a mix of reactions around the world, with some hailing the operation as a major success in the fight against terrorism and others criticizing the use of drone strikes and the targeting of a prominent militant leader.

## Al-Qaeda response

Al-Qaeda issued a statement confirming al-Zawahiri's death and vowing to continue the group's campaign of global jihad. The statement, released on August 1, 2022, praised al-Zawahiri as a "martyr" and a "hero of the Islamic ummah." Al-Qaeda also warned of "severe repercussions" for the United States and its allies in response to the killing.

## U.S. politicians

U.S. President Joe Biden hailed the operation as a major success, saying that al-Zawahiri's death marked a "significant blow" to al-Qaeda. Biden also praised the bravery and skill of the U.S. military and intelligence agencies involved in the operation.

Other U.S. politicians, including Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, also issued statements congratulating the administration on the success of the operation.

## Taliban

The Taliban, which had taken control of Afghanistan in August 2021, condemned the drone strike as a "violation of Afghan sovereignty." Taliban spokesperson Zabiullah Mujahid said that the group had not been aware of al-Zawahiri's presence in Kabul and that the strike was a "clear violation of international law."

## International governments

The United Kingdom, France, and other European countries issued statements welcoming the news of al-Zawahiri's death and praising the efforts of the U.S. military and intelligence agencies.

The United Nations Security Council also issued a statement condemning al-Qaeda and its affiliates, while also calling for restraint and respect for international law in the fight against terrorism.

## Individuals

Former U.S. President Barack Obama, who had authorized the operation that killed Osama bin Laden in 2011, issued a statement congratulating President Biden on the success of the operation.

Other individuals, including former CIA Director John Brennan and former U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, also praised the operation and the bravery of the U.S. military and intelligence agencies involved.

article:
Illegal Operation (Euphemism)

An "illegal operation" is a euphemism that was historically used to refer to an abortion, particularly in the United States during the mid-20th century. The term was employed to avoid direct mention of the procedure, which was often stigmatized and subject to restrictions. This article explores the history, law, and representation of "illegal operation" in art, including film, television, sculpture, and fiction.

# History

## Background

In the early 20th century, abortion was a highly controversial and often illicit practice in the United States. Many states had laws prohibiting the procedure, except in cases where the mother's life was at risk. As a result, women seeking abortions often had to resort to clandestine and unregulated methods, which could lead to serious health risks and even death. The term "illegal operation" emerged as a way to refer to these clandestine abortions without explicitly stating their nature.

## "The thing that had no name"

During the 1920s and 1930s, the term "illegal operation" became more widely used in medical and journalistic contexts. It was often employed to describe a procedure that was not explicitly stated, allowing writers and speakers to avoid direct mention of abortion. This euphemism was particularly useful in cases where the procedure was performed by a licensed physician, but without the proper authorization or in a non-medical setting.

## Abortion euphemism elsewhere in print

The use of "illegal operation" as a euphemism for abortion was not unique to the United States. In the United Kingdom, for example, the term "criminal operation" was used in similar contexts. In France, the phrase "avortement clandestin" (clandestine abortion) was used to describe the procedure. These euphemisms reflect the widespread stigma and restrictions surrounding abortion during this period.

# Law

The use of "illegal operation" as a euphemism for abortion was closely tied to the legal restrictions surrounding the procedure. In the United States, the Comstock laws of the late 19th century had prohibited the distribution of information and materials related to abortion, as well as the procedure itself. Many states had laws that restricted or prohibited abortion, except in cases where the mother's life was at risk.

The term "illegal operation" often appeared in court cases and police reports related to abortion. For example, a 1930s court case in New York City involved a physician who was charged with performing an "illegal operation" on a woman who had sought an abortion. The use of this euphemism in legal contexts reflects the ambiguity and secrecy surrounding abortion during this period.

# Art

The term "illegal operation" has been represented in various forms of art, including film, television, sculpture, and fiction.

## Film

In the 1930s and 1940s, films often used the term "illegal operation" to refer to abortion, rather than explicitly stating the procedure. For example, the 1934 film "Men in White" features a scene in which a character undergoes an "illegal operation" performed by a physician. This euphemism was used to avoid censorship and to convey the risks and stigma surrounding abortion.

## Television

In the 1950s and 1960s, television shows often used the term "illegal operation" to refer to abortion, particularly in dramas and soap operas. For example, the 1950s television show "Ben Casey" featured an episode in which a character undergoes an "illegal operation" performed by a physician. This euphemism was used to convey the risks and consequences of seeking an abortion.

## Sculpture

The term "illegal operation" has been represented in sculpture, particularly in works that explore themes of abortion and reproductive rights. For example, the 1970s sculpture "Abortion" by artist Judy Chicago features a series of images and texts that refer to the procedure, including the term "illegal operation." This work reflects the artist's efforts to raise awareness and challenge the stigma surrounding abortion.

## Fiction

The term "illegal operation" has been used in fiction, particularly in novels and short stories that explore themes of abortion and reproductive rights. For example, the 1960s novel "The Group" by Mary McCarthy features a character who undergoes an "illegal operation" performed by a physician. This euphemism is used to convey the risks and stigma surrounding abortion, as well as the character's experiences and emotions.

article:
Gujarat Titans
================

The Gujarat Titans are a professional Twenty20 cricket franchise based in Ahmedabad, Gujarat, India. The team was founded in 2021 and plays in the Indian Premier League (IPL), one of the most popular and competitive T20 leagues in the world. The team is owned by CVC Capital Partners, a private equity firm, and is one of the two new teams introduced in the IPL in 2022, along with the Lucknow Super Giants.

Franchise history
-----------------

The Gujarat Titans were founded in 2021 when the Board of Control for Cricket in India (BCCI) announced the introduction of two new teams in the Indian Premier League. The team was owned by CVC Capital Partners, a private equity firm, which won the bid for the Ahmedabad-based franchise with a bid of ₹5,625 crore (US$750 million).

The team was officially unveiled on February 9, 2022, with Hardik Pandya, a former Mumbai Indians player, as the team's captain. The team's name, Gujarat Titans, was chosen to reflect the state's rich cultural heritage and its reputation for producing successful entrepreneurs and business leaders.

Team history
-------------

The Gujarat Titans played their first match in the IPL on March 28, 2022, against the Lucknow Super Giants at the Wankhede Stadium in Mumbai. The team won the match by 5 wickets, with Hardik Pandya scoring 33 runs off 30 balls.

In their inaugural season, the Gujarat Titans finished the league stage with 10 wins and 4 losses, qualifying for the playoffs. They defeated the Royal Challengers Bangalore in the Eliminator match and then lost to the Rajasthan Royals in the Qualifier 1 match. The team eventually lost to the Royal Challengers Bangalore in the Qualifier 2 match, finishing the season in third place.

article:
Kirstie Alley
================

Kirstie Alley is a renowned American actress, comedian, and television personality, best known for her iconic roles in popular television shows and films. With a career spanning over four decades, Alley has established herself as a household name, showcasing her versatility and talent in various genres. This article delves into her life, career, and legacy, exploring her early years, professional accomplishments, personal life, and impact on the entertainment industry.

Early life and education
------------------------

Kirstie Alley was born on January 12, 1951, in Wichita, Kansas, to Robert Deal Alley, a lumber company owner, and Lillian Alley, a homemaker. She was raised in a middle-class family with two siblings, Craig and Colette. Alley's early life was marked by a strong interest in the performing arts, particularly dance and comedy. She began taking dance lessons at the age of 16 and later attended Wichita Southeast High School.

After graduating from high school, Alley moved to Kansas City, where she worked as an interior designer and a cocktail waitress. In 1979, she relocated to Los Angeles to pursue a career in comedy, enrolling in a comedy workshop at the legendary Comedy Store.

Career
-------

Kirstie Alley's career in the entertainment industry began in the late 1970s, with appearances on game shows, including "Match Game" and "Password." Her breakthrough role came in 1982 when she played the character of Lieutenant Junior Grade Saavik in the science fiction film "Star Trek II: The Wrath of Khan." Although she was initially cast as a minor character, her performance earned her recognition and led to more significant roles in film and television.

In 1987, Alley landed the iconic role of Rebecca Howe on the popular television sitcom "Cheers," which catapulted her to stardom. Her portrayal of the lovable, yet sassy and manipulative bar manager earned her multiple Emmy nominations and a Golden Globe Award.

Throughout the 1990s and 2000s, Alley appeared in various films, including "Look Who's Talking," "It Takes Two," and "Deconstructing Harry." She also made numerous television appearances, including starring roles in "Veronica's Closet" and "Fat Actress," a semi-autobiographical comedy series that aired on Showtime.

In recent years, Alley has continued to work in television, appearing in shows such as "Dancing with the Stars" and "The Goldbergs." Her most recent role was as a contestant on the British reality show "I'm a Celebrity...Get Me Out of Here!" in 2018.

Personal life
-------------

### Body image

Kirstie Alley has been open about her struggles with weight and body image throughout her career. In the 1990s, she gained a significant amount of weight, which led to public scrutiny and media attention. Alley has since spoken about her experiences with weight loss and gain, using her platform to promote self-acceptance and body positivity.

### Scientology

Alley is a member of the Church of Scientology, a controversial organization founded by L. Ron Hubbard. She has been a vocal supporter of the church, crediting it with helping her overcome personal struggles and achieve success in her career. Alley has faced criticism for her association with the church, which has been accused of promoting pseudoscience and mistreating its members.

### Politics

Kirstie Alley has been an outspoken supporter of the Republican Party, publicly endorsing candidates such as Donald Trump and Mitt Romney. She has also expressed conservative views on social media, sparking controversy and debate among her fans and followers.

Death
------

Kirstie Alley passed away on December 5, 2022, after a short illness. Her death was met with an outpouring of tributes and condolences from fans, colleagues, and fellow celebrities, who remembered her as a talented and beloved figure in the entertainment industry.

article:
Renaissance is the seventh studio album by American singer Beyoncé, released on July 29, 2022, by Parkwood Entertainment and Columbia Records. The album marks a return to Beyoncé's solo work after a six-year hiatus, following the release of her 2016 visual album Lemonade.

# Background and conception

Renaissance was conceived during the COVID-19 pandemic, a time of great personal and professional change for Beyoncé. The album's creation was influenced by the singer's experiences as a mother, a wife, and an artist, as well as her desire to explore new sounds and themes. Beyoncé has stated that the album is a celebration of freedom, joy, and self-expression, and that it was inspired by her own journey towards healing and liberation.

The album's title, Renaissance, refers to the cultural and artistic movement of the same name, which saw a resurgence of interest in classical Greek and Roman culture in 14th-century Europe. Beyoncé has said that she chose the title because it represents a time of great change and transformation, and that she sees her own music as a way of sparking a similar cultural renaissance.

# Cover artwork

The cover artwork for Renaissance features a photograph of Beyoncé riding a horse, taken by Carlijn Jacobs. The image is a nod to the classic equestrian portraits of the Renaissance era, and features Beyoncé in a custom-made outfit designed by Nusi Quero. The cover has been praised for its striking beauty and its celebration of black female empowerment.

# Composition

Renaissance is a musical departure from Beyoncé's previous work, incorporating a range of styles and genres, including house, disco, and Afrobeats. The album features 16 tracks, each of which showcases Beyoncé's vocal range and emotional depth. The album's lyrics explore themes of love, identity, and self-discovery, and feature a range of references to art, literature, and history.

The album's production was handled by a range of collaborators, including Skrillex, The-Dream, and D-Dot. Beyoncé has said that she was inspired by the work of classic disco and soul artists, such as Donna Summer and Chaka Khan, and that she sought to capture the same sense of energy and excitement on Renaissance.

# Promotion and release

## Singles

The first single from Renaissance, "Break My Soul", was released on June 20, 2022. The song was a critical and commercial success, reaching number one on the US Billboard Hot 100 chart and becoming Beyoncé's eighth number-one single. The song's music video, directed by Beyoncé and her longtime collaborator, Ed Burke, features a range of dancers and performers, and celebrates the joy and liberation of dance.

## Tour

Beyoncé embarked on a world tour in support of Renaissance, which kicked off in Stockholm, Sweden on May 10, 2023. The tour features a range of high-energy performances, including a medley of Beyoncé's greatest hits and a selection of tracks from Renaissance. The tour has been praised for its stunning visuals and choreography, and has broken box office records around the world.

## Visuals

The visuals for Renaissance are a key part of the album's overall aesthetic and message. The album's music videos, directed by Beyoncé and a range of collaborators, feature a range of striking images and performances, and celebrate the beauty and diversity of black culture. The videos have been praised for their creativity and innovation, and have been viewed millions of times on YouTube and other platforms.

## Renaissance Couture

In support of the album, Beyoncé launched a range of fashion collaborations, including a limited-edition collection with Adidas and a bespoke fashion line with Balmain. The collections feature a range of striking designs and silhouettes, and celebrate Beyoncé's status as a fashion icon and trendsetter.

# Reception

## Critical response

Renaissance was widely praised by critics upon its release, with many praising the album's innovative production, lyrical depth, and Beyoncé's vocal range and emotional delivery. The album has been described as a "masterpiece" and a "game-changer" by critics, and has been praised for its celebration of black culture and identity.

## Featured, sampled and interpolated artists

Renaissance features a range of collaborations and interpolations, including contributions from Jay-Z, Drake, and Tems. The album also samples a range of classic tracks, including Donna Summer's "I Feel Love" and Chaka Khan's "I'm Every Woman".

# Accolades

## Awards

Renaissance has been nominated for a range of awards, including the Grammy Award for Album of the Year. The album has also won a number of awards, including the BET Award for Album of the Year and the MTV Video Music Award for Video of the Year.

## Year-end rankings

Renaissance has been included on a number of year-end lists, including Rolling Stone's 50 Best Albums of 2022 and Pitchfork's 50 Best Albums of 2022. The album has also been named one of the best albums of the decade by a number of publications, including The New York Times and The Guardian.

# Commercial performance

## United States

Renaissance debuted at number one on the US Billboard 200 chart, with sales of over 300,000 copies in its first week. The album has been certified platinum by the RIAA and has spent several weeks at number one on the US Billboard 200 chart.

## Internationally

Renaissance has been a commercial success internationally, reaching number one on the charts in a number of countries, including the UK, Canada, and Australia. The album has been certified multi-platinum in several countries and has spent several weeks at number one on the international charts.

# Legacy

Renaissance is widely regarded as one of the best albums of the 2020s, and has been praised for its innovative production, lyrical depth, and Beyoncé's vocal range and emotional delivery. The album has been named one of the best albums of the decade by a number of publications, including The New York Times and The Guardian.

article:
Sardar (2022 film)

Sardar is a 2022 Indian Tamil-language action thriller film written and directed by P. S. Mithran. The film stars Karthi in the titular role, alongside Raashii Khanna, Rajisha Vijayan, and Chunky Panday. The movie follows the story of a spy who must use his skills to uncover the truth behind a conspiracy.

# Plot

The film opens with Vijay (Karthi), a renowned spy who has been living in hiding for several years. He is forced to come out of retirement when he discovers that a conspiracy is brewing in the country. As Vijay delves deeper into the mystery, he realizes that it is linked to a series of events from his past.

Vijay's investigation takes him from Chennai to Delhi, where he encounters a range of characters, including a young journalist named Shalini (Raashii Khanna) and a mysterious woman named Advik (Rajisha Vijayan). As Vijay gets closer to the truth, he must use his skills and resources to stay one step ahead of his enemies.

Throughout the film, Vijay's character is shown to be a complex and multi-faceted individual, with a deep sense of loyalty and duty. His backstory is slowly revealed, showing how he became a spy and the events that led him to go into hiding.

The film's climax features an intense showdown between Vijay and the mastermind behind the conspiracy. The action sequence is well-choreographed, with Karthi performing many of his own stunts.

# Cast

* Raashii Khanna as Shalini

# Production

## Development

The film was first announced in 2020, with Karthi and P. S. Mithran attached to the project. The script was written by Mithran, who is known for his work on films like "Abhimanyudu" and "Irumbu Thirai".

According to Karthi, he was drawn to the project because of the complexity of the character and the scope of the story. He spent several months preparing for the role, including undergoing physical training and learning new skills.

## Casting

The cast of the film was announced in several stages, with Raashii Khanna and Rajisha Vijayan being confirmed as the female leads. Chunky Panday was cast as the main antagonist, marking his Tamil film debut.

The film also features a number of supporting actors, including Laila and Murali Sharma. The cast underwent extensive rehearsals before filming began.

## Filming

Principal photography began in January 2021 and took place in several locations, including Chennai, Delhi, and Hyderabad. The film was shot on a relatively modest budget, with a focus on practical effects and stunts.

Karthi performed many of his own stunts, including a notable sequence where he fights off a group of henchmen in a hotel lobby. The film's action sequences were choreographed by a team of stunt directors, including Anbariv.

# Music

The film's soundtrack was composed by G. V. Prakash Kumar, with lyrics by Kabilan and Madhan Karky. The album features five tracks, including the hit single "Yaaraiyum Ivlo Azhaga".

The music was well-received by critics and audiences alike, with many praising the composer's use of traditional instruments and melodies.

# Release

## Theatrical

The film was released in theaters on October 21, 2022, in Tamil Nadu and other parts of India. It received a mixed response from critics, with many praising the film's action sequences and performances.

The film opened at number one at the box office, with a strong opening weekend. However, it faced stiff competition from other releases and ultimately underperformed at the box office.

## Distribution

The film was distributed by Prince Pictures, a leading film distribution company in Tamil Nadu. The company has a strong track record of releasing successful films in the region.

## Home media

The film was released on digital platforms in November 2022, with a DVD and Blu-ray release following in December.

# Reception

The film received mixed reviews from critics, with many praising the performances and action sequences. However, some critics felt that the film's story was overly complex and that the pacing was uneven.

Audiences were also divided, with some praising the film's entertainment value and others feeling that it was too long and convoluted.

# Sequel

There have been reports of a potential sequel to the film, with Karthi and P. S. Mithran set to return. However, no official announcement has been made.

article:
Climate Change Mitigation

Climate change mitigation refers to the actions taken to reduce the severity of climate change by decreasing greenhouse gas emissions and enhancing carbon sinks. The goal of mitigation is to limit the magnitude of long-term climate change and its associated impacts on the environment, human health, and the economy. Mitigation efforts can be implemented at various levels, from individual actions to international agreements, and involve a range of strategies, including transitioning to low-carbon energy sources, increasing energy efficiency, and protecting and reforestation.

Definitions and scope

Climate change mitigation is closely related to climate change adaptation, which involves taking actions to reduce the impacts of climate change that are already occurring or are likely to occur in the future. While adaptation focuses on responding to the effects of climate change, mitigation focuses on reducing the root cause of the problem by decreasing greenhouse gas emissions.

Relationship with solar radiation modification (SRM)

Solar radiation modification (SRM) refers to a set of technologies that aim to reflect a small percentage of the sun's radiation back into space, thereby reducing the amount of energy that enters the Earth's atmosphere. SRM is often discussed as a potential complement to mitigation efforts, as it could potentially provide a rapid and cost-effective way to reduce global temperatures. However, SRM is still a highly speculative and controversial technology, and its potential impacts on the environment and human societies are not yet fully understood.

Emission trends and pledges

Needed emissions cuts

In order to limit global warming to well below 2°C (3.6°F) above pre-industrial levels, as agreed upon in the Paris Agreement, it is estimated that global greenhouse gas emissions need to be reduced by 45% by 2030 and reach net-zero by 2050. However, current country pledges under the Paris Agreement are not sufficient to meet this goal, and emissions are expected to continue to rise in the coming decades.

Pledges

Countries have made various pledges to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions, including commitments to increase the use of renewable energy, improve energy efficiency, and protect forests. However, these pledges are not always binding, and their effectiveness in reducing emissions is often uncertain.

Low-carbon energy

Solar and wind energy

Solar and wind energy are two of the fastest-growing sources of low-carbon energy globally. The cost of these technologies has decreased dramatically in recent years, making them more competitive with fossil fuels in many parts of the world. Solar and wind energy can be used to generate electricity, power transportation, and provide heat and cooling.

Other renewables

In addition to solar and wind energy, other low-carbon energy sources include hydroelectric power, geothermal energy, and biomass. These energy sources can provide baseload power, which is essential for ensuring a stable and reliable energy supply.

Integrating variable renewable energy

One of the challenges of integrating variable renewable energy sources, such as solar and wind energy, into the grid is that they are not always available when they are needed. To address this challenge, grid operators are using advanced weather forecasting and energy storage technologies to ensure a stable and reliable energy supply.

Nuclear power

Nuclear power is a low-carbon energy source that can provide baseload power. However, the use of nuclear power is often controversial due to concerns about nuclear safety and waste disposal.

Replacing coal with natural gas

Replacing coal with natural gas is often touted as a way to reduce greenhouse gas emissions from the energy sector. However, natural gas is still a fossil fuel, and its production and use can have significant environmental impacts, including methane leaks and water pollution.

Demand reduction

Energy conservation and efficiency

Improving energy efficiency and reducing energy consumption are critical components of climate change mitigation. This can be achieved through the development and use of more efficient technologies, such as LED lighting and smart appliances, as well as through changes in behavior, such as turning off lights and electronics when not in use.

Lifestyle changes

Changes in lifestyle, such as reducing meat consumption and using public transportation, can also play an important role in reducing energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions.

Dietary change

Animal agriculture is a significant source of greenhouse gas emissions, and reducing meat consumption can help to mitigate climate change. A plant-based diet can also have numerous health benefits.

Family size

Family size is another factor that can impact greenhouse gas emissions, as larger families tend to have a larger carbon footprint. Reducing family size can therefore be an effective way to reduce emissions.

Preserving and enhancing carbon sinks

Forests

Conservation

Forest conservation is critical for maintaining carbon sinks and mitigating climate change. Forests absorb carbon dioxide from the atmosphere and store it in trees, soil, and other biomass.

Afforestation and reforestation

Planting new trees and restoring degraded forests can also help to enhance carbon sinks. This can be achieved through government programs, community-led initiatives, and private sector investments.

Soils

Soils are another important carbon sink, and preserving and enhancing soil health can help to mitigate climate change. This can be achieved through sustainable agriculture practices, such as agroforestry and permaculture.

Wetlands

Wetlands, including mangroves, marshes, and peatlands, are critical carbon sinks that provide numerous ecosystem services, including water filtration and habitat provision.

Deep ocean

The deep ocean is a significant carbon sink, and preserving and enhancing its health can help to mitigate climate change. This can be achieved through the protection of marine ecosystems, including coral reefs and sea mounts.

Enhanced weathering

Enhanced weathering involves the use of minerals to absorb carbon dioxide from the atmosphere. This can be achieved through the application of minerals to soils, as well as through the use of mineral-rich fertilizers.

Other methods to capture and store CO2

In addition to preserving and enhancing carbon sinks, other methods to capture and store CO2 include carbon capture and storage (CCS) technologies, which involve the capture of CO2 emissions from power plants and industrial processes, followed by storage in geological formations.

Mitigation by sector

Buildings

The building sector is a significant source of greenhouse gas emissions, and mitigating climate change will require changes in building design, construction, and operation. This can be achieved through the use of more efficient building materials, as well as through changes in behavior, such as turning off lights and electronics when not in use.

Urban planning

Urban planning can also play an important role in mitigating climate change, by designing cities that are more efficient, sustainable, and resilient. This can be achieved through the creation of green spaces, the promotion of public transportation, and the development of more efficient building designs.

Transport

Shipping

The shipping sector is a significant source of greenhouse gas emissions, and mitigating climate change will require changes in ship design, operation, and fuel use. This can be achieved through the use of more efficient ship designs, as well as through the development of alternative fuels, such as hydrogen and wind power.

Air transport

The air transport sector is also a significant source of greenhouse gas emissions, and mitigating climate change will require changes in aircraft design, operation, and fuel use. This can be achieved through the use of more efficient aircraft designs, as well as through the development of alternative fuels, such as biofuels and electric propulsion.

Agriculture, forestry and land use

The agriculture, forestry, and land use sector is a significant source of greenhouse gas emissions, and mitigating climate change will require changes in agricultural practices, forest management, and land use. This can be achieved through the adoption of more sustainable agricultural practices, such as agroforestry and permaculture, as well as through the protection and restoration of forests.

Industry

The industry sector is a significant source of greenhouse gas emissions, and mitigating climate change will require changes in industrial processes, technologies, and practices. This can be achieved through the development and use of more efficient technologies, as well as through changes in behavior, such as reducing energy consumption and waste generation.

Co-benefits

Employment and economic development

Mitigating climate change can have numerous co-benefits, including the creation of new employment opportunities and the stimulation of economic development. This can be achieved through the development of new industries, such as renewable energy and sustainable agriculture, as well as through the creation of new jobs in fields such as energy efficiency and sustainable infrastructure.

Energy security

Mitigating climate change can also improve energy security, by reducing dependence on fossil fuels and promoting the development of renewable energy sources. This can be achieved through the development of new energy technologies, as well as through the creation of new energy infrastructure, such as smart grids and energy storage systems.

Health and well-being

Mitigating climate change can also have numerous health benefits, including the reduction of air pollution and the promotion of physical activity. This can be achieved through the development of new transportation systems, such as cycling and walking infrastructure, as well as through the creation of new green spaces and parks.

Climate change adaptation

Mitigating climate change can also help to promote climate change adaptation, by reducing the impacts of climate change and promoting resilience. This can be achieved through the development of new technologies and practices, such as climate-resilient agriculture and infrastructure, as well as through the creation of new early warning systems and emergency preparedness plans.

Negative side effects

While mitigating climate change can have numerous benefits, it can also have negative side effects, including the displacement of communities and the destruction of natural habitats. This can be achieved through the development of new infrastructure, such as wind farms and solar parks, as well as through the creation of new industries, such as biofuels and carbon capture and storage.

Costs and funding

Avoided costs of climate change effects

Mitigating climate change can help to avoid the costs of climate change effects, including the damage to infrastructure, the loss of productivity, and the impacts on human health. This can be achieved through the development of new technologies and practices, such as climate-resilient infrastructure and climate-smart agriculture, as well as through the creation of new early warning systems and emergency preparedness plans.

Distributing emissions abatement costs

Mitigating climate change will require the distribution of emissions abatement costs, including the costs of transitioning to low-carbon energy sources, improving energy efficiency, and protecting and restoring natural ecosystems. This can be achieved through the creation of new economic instruments, such as carbon pricing and green bonds, as well as through the development of new international agreements and cooperation mechanisms.

Funding

Mitigating climate change will require significant funding, including public and private sector investments in low-carbon energy sources, energy efficiency, and natural ecosystem protection and restoration. This can be achieved through the creation of new funding mechanisms, such as green climate funds and climate bonds, as well as through the mobilization of existing funding sources, such as development banks and private sector investors.

Policies

National policies

Carbon pricing

Carbon pricing is a key policy instrument for mitigating climate change, as it provides a financial incentive for reducing greenhouse gas emissions. This can be achieved through the creation of carbon taxes, cap-and-trade systems, and other economic instruments.

International agreements

Paris Agreement

The Paris Agreement is a key international agreement for mitigating climate change, as it sets a global goal for limiting global warming to well below 2°C (3.6°F) above pre-industrial levels. This can be achieved through the creation of national pledges, international cooperation, and the mobilization of climate finance.

History

The history of climate change mitigation dates back to the 1980s, when the first international agreements on climate change were established. Since then, climate change mitigation has become a major priority for governments, businesses, and civil society organizations around the world.

Society and culture

Commitments to divest

Commitments to divest from fossil fuels have become a major trend in recent years, as individuals and institutions seek to reduce their carbon footprint and promote climate change mitigation. This can be achieved through the divestment of fossil fuel stocks, the creation of fossil fuel-free investment portfolios, and the promotion of climate-resilient infrastructure.

Barriers

Despite the growing momentum behind climate change mitigation, there are still significant barriers to overcome, including the lack of political will, the vested interests of fossil fuel companies, and the limited availability of climate finance. This can be achieved through the creation of new policies and regulations, the mobilization of public opinion, and the development of new technologies and practices.

Impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a significant impact on climate change mitigation, as governments and businesses have been forced to respond to the immediate crisis. However, the pandemic has also provided an opportunity to promote climate change mitigation, as governments and businesses seek to build back better and promote sustainable development.

Examples by country

United States

The United States has been a major player in climate change mitigation, with significant investments in low-carbon energy sources, energy efficiency, and natural ecosystem protection and restoration. However, the country has also been criticized for its slow pace of progress and its withdrawal from the Paris Agreement.

China

China has become a major leader in climate change mitigation, with significant investments in low-carbon energy sources, energy efficiency, and natural ecosystem protection and restoration. The country has also been a major player in international climate negotiations, including the Paris Agreement.

European Union

The European Union has been a major leader in climate change mitigation, with significant investments in low-carbon energy sources, energy efficiency, and natural ecosystem protection and restoration. The EU has also been a major player in international climate negotiations, including the Paris Agreement.

2023 CONCACAF U-17 Championship

The 2023 CONCACAF U-17 Championship is the 7th edition of the CONCACAF U-17 Championship, the men's under-17 international football tournament organized by CONCACAF. The tournament will determine the four CONCACAF representatives at the 2023 FIFA U-17 World Cup in Indonesia.

# Qualified teams

A total of 20 teams from CONCACAF will participate in the tournament. The teams are:

*  Aruba
*  Barbados
*  Belize
*  Canada
*  Costa Rica
*  Cuba

*  El Salvador

# Venues

The draw for the group stage took place on 21 January 2023 in Miami, Florida. The teams were divided into four groups of five teams each.

article:
Grade (climbing)
================

Climbing grades are systems used to measure the difficulty of ascents in rock climbing, ice climbing, and mountaineering. These systems are crucial in facilitating communication among climbers, guiding climbers in selecting routes that match their abilities, and providing a framework for assessing and comparing the challenges posed by different climbs. The various grading systems have evolved over time, influenced by regional climbing traditions, advances in climbing techniques, and the development of new climbing areas.

History
-------

The concept of grading climbs dates back to the early 20th century, when European climbers began assigning difficulty levels to routes. The first grading system, developed in the 1890s, used a simple "difficulty" scale with three levels: easy, medium, and hard. As climbing became more popular and widespread, the need for more nuanced and standardized grading systems grew. Over the years, various regions and climbing communities developed their own unique grading systems, often reflecting local climbing styles, terrain, and cultural influences.

Free Climbing
=============

Free climbing is a style of climbing that involves ascending a rock face without the use of aid equipment, relying solely on the climber's physical abilities and technical skills.

### French Numerical Grade

The French numerical grade system, also known as the "French scale," is one of the most widely used grading systems in free climbing. Developed in the 1970s, this system assigns a numerical grade from 1 to 9, with additional suffixes (a, b, c, etc.) to indicate further gradations of difficulty. The French system is considered relatively precise, with small increments in grade reflecting distinct increases in difficulty.

### American YDS Grade

The Yosemite Decimal System (YDS) is a grading system used in the United States, primarily in the western states. Developed in the 1950s, YDS grades range from Class 1 (easy walking) to Class 5 (technical climbing). Within Class 5, there are ten subclasses (5.0 to 5.10), each representing a distinct level of difficulty. The YDS system has been adopted by many climbing areas in the United States, although some regions have developed their own variations.

### UIAA Scale

The Union of International Alpine Associations (UIAA) scale is a grading system used in many European countries, particularly in the Alps. This system assigns a grade from I (easy) to XI (extremely difficult), with additional suffixes (a, b, c, etc.) to indicate further gradations of difficulty. The UIAA scale is considered relatively broad, with larger increments in grade reflecting more significant increases in difficulty.

### British E-Grade

The British E-grade system, also known as the "E-grade scale," is used in the United Kingdom and Ireland. Developed in the 1970s, this system assigns a grade from E1 (relatively easy) to E9 (extremely difficult), with additional suffixes (a, b, c, etc.) to indicate further gradations of difficulty. The E-grade system is considered relatively precise, with small increments in grade reflecting distinct increases in difficulty.

### Other Notable Systems

Other notable grading systems used in free climbing include the Australian V-grade system, the Canadian 5.0 to 5.15 system, and the South African grading system.

Bouldering
==========

Bouldering is a style of climbing that involves ascending short, lower-level rock formations, typically without the use of ropes or harnesses.

### Comparison with Free Climbing

Bouldering grades are generally considered to be more subjective than free climbing grades, as the difficulty of a bouldering problem can depend on the individual climber's style and technique. However, many bouldering areas use grading systems that are similar to those used in free climbing.

### Font Grade

The Font grade system is used in the Fontainebleau region of France and is one of the most widely used grading systems in bouldering. Developed in the 1980s, this system assigns a grade from 1 to 8, with additional suffixes (a, b, c, etc.) to indicate further gradations of difficulty.

### V-Grade

The V-grade system is used in the United States and is similar to the Font grade system. Developed in the 1990s, this system assigns a grade from V0 (relatively easy) to V16 (extremely difficult), with additional suffixes (a, b, c, etc.) to indicate further gradations of difficulty.

### Other Notable Systems

Other notable grading systems used in bouldering include the British V-grade system, the Canadian V-grade system, and the Australian V-grade system.

Aid Climbing
============

Aid climbing is a style of climbing that involves using equipment, such as ladders, hooks, and cams, to assist in ascending a rock face.

### Instability of Aid Grades

Aid grades are generally considered to be more subjective and less stable than free climbing grades, as the difficulty of an aid climb can depend on the individual climber's experience and technique with aid equipment.

### Original A-Grade

The original A-grade system was developed in the 1960s and assigned a grade from A0 (relatively easy) to A5 (extremely difficult). However, this system has largely been replaced by more modern grading systems.

### New Wave A-Grade

The new wave A-grade system was developed in the 1980s and assigns a grade from A0 (relatively easy) to A6 (extremely difficult), with additional suffixes (a, b, c, etc.) to indicate further gradations of difficulty.

### Clean C-Grade

The clean C-grade system is used in some aid climbing areas and assigns a grade from C0 (relatively easy) to C5 (extremely difficult), with additional suffixes (a, b, c, etc.) to indicate further gradations of difficulty.

Ice and Mixed Climbing
=====================

Ice climbing involves ascending ice formations, such as icefalls or glaciers, using specialized equipment, such as ice axes and crampons. Mixed climbing involves ascending routes that combine ice and rock.

### WI-Grade

The WI-grade system is used in ice climbing and assigns a grade from WI1 (relatively easy) to WI7 (extremely difficult), with additional suffixes (a, b, c, etc.) to indicate further gradations of difficulty.

### M-Grade

The M-grade system is used in mixed climbing and assigns a grade from M1 (relatively easy) to M12 (extremely difficult), with additional suffixes (a, b, c, etc.) to indicate further gradations of difficulty.

### D-Grade

The D-grade system is used in some ice climbing areas and assigns a grade from D1 (relatively easy) to D7 (extremely difficult), with additional suffixes (a, b, c, etc.) to indicate further gradations of difficulty.

### Scottish Winter Grade

The Scottish winter grade system is used in Scotland and assigns a grade from I (relatively easy) to VII (extremely difficult), with additional suffixes (a, b, c, etc.) to indicate further gradations of difficulty.

### Other Notable Systems

Other notable grading systems used in ice and mixed climbing include the American ice grade system, the Canadian ice grade system, and the Norwegian ice grade system.

Mountaineering
==============

Mountaineering involves ascending mountains, often using a combination of climbing, hiking, and skiing techniques.

### International French Adjectival System

The International French Adjectival System (IFAS) is used in mountaineering and assigns a grade from F (relatively easy) to ED (extremely difficult), with additional suffixes (a, b, c, etc.) to indicate further gradations of difficulty.

### American NCCS

The National Climbing Classification System (NCCS) is used in the United States and assigns a grade from Class 1 (relatively easy) to Class 5 (extremely difficult), with additional suffixes (a, b, c, etc.) to indicate further gradations of difficulty.

### Russian

The Russian grading system is used in Russia and assigns a grade from 1A (relatively easy) to 6B (extremely difficult), with additional suffixes (a, b, c, etc.) to indicate further gradations of difficulty.

### Alaskan

The Alaskan grading system is used in Alaska and assigns a grade from Class 1 (relatively easy) to Class 5 (extremely difficult), with additional suffixes (a, b, c, etc.) to indicate further gradations of difficulty.

### Other Notable Systems

Tropical Cyclones in 2023

The year 2023 witnessed a significant number of tropical cyclones across the globe, resulting in substantial damage and loss of life. This article provides a comprehensive overview of the global atmospheric and hydrological conditions, a summary of the tropical cyclones that occurred in each basin, and a detailed account of the systems that developed throughout the year.

# Global Atmospheric and Hydrological Conditions

The global atmospheric and hydrological conditions in 2023 were influenced by various climate patterns, including the El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) and the Indian Ocean Dipole (IOD). The ENSO cycle, which affects the Pacific Ocean, transitioned from a La Niña event in 2022 to a neutral phase in 2023. This transition led to changes in the atmospheric circulation patterns, resulting in increased hurricane activity in the North Atlantic and a more active monsoon season in the North Indian Ocean.

The IOD, which affects the Indian Ocean, was in a positive phase during the first half of 2023, leading to above-average rainfall in the eastern parts of Africa and below-average rainfall in the western parts of Australia. The positive IOD phase also contributed to the development of tropical cyclones in the South-West Indian Ocean.

# Summary

## North Atlantic Ocean

The 2023 North Atlantic hurricane season was above-average, with 14 named storms, 7 hurricanes, and 2 major hurricanes. The season began with the formation of Tropical Storm Arlene in May and ended with the dissipation of Hurricane Nicole in November. The most notable storm of the season was Hurricane Idalia, which made landfall in Florida as a Category 3 hurricane, causing significant damage and flooding.

## Eastern & Central Pacific Ocean

The 2023 Eastern Pacific hurricane season was near-average, with 15 named storms, 8 hurricanes, and 2 major hurricanes. The season began with the formation of Tropical Storm Adrian in May and ended with the dissipation of Hurricane Raymond in November. The most notable storm of the season was Hurricane Hilary, which made landfall in Baja California as a Category 3 hurricane, causing significant damage and power outages.

## Western Pacific Ocean

The 2023 Western Pacific typhoon season was above-average, with 26 named storms, 14 typhoons, and 6 super typhoons. The season began with the formation of Tropical Storm Sanvu in February and ended with the dissipation of Super Typhoon Vongfong in December. The most notable storm of the season was Super Typhoon Kong-rey, which made landfall in Japan as a Category 5-equivalent super typhoon, causing significant damage and flooding.

## North Indian Ocean

The 2023 North Indian Ocean cyclone season was above-average, with 10 named storms, 5 cyclones, and 2 super cyclones. The season began with the formation of Cyclone Sagar in May and ended with the dissipation of Super Cyclone Titli in November. The most notable storm of the season was Super Cyclone Phethai, which made landfall in Odisha as a Category 4-equivalent super cyclone, causing significant damage and flooding.

## South-West Indian Ocean

### January - June

The 2023 South-West Indian Ocean cyclone season was near-average, with 5 named storms, 2 cyclones, and 1 intense tropical cyclone. The season began with the formation of Tropical Storm Cebile in January and ended with the dissipation of Intense Tropical Cyclone Freddy in June.

### July - December

The 2023 South-West Indian Ocean cyclone season was above-average, with 8 named storms, 4 cyclones, and 2 intense tropical cyclones. The season began with the formation of Tropical Storm Gombe in July and ended with the dissipation of Intense Tropical Cyclone Idai in December. The most notable storm of the season was Intense Tropical Cyclone Hellen, which made landfall in Mozambique as a Category 4-equivalent intense tropical cyclone, causing significant damage and flooding.

## Australian region

### January - June

The 2023 Australian region cyclone season was near-average, with 5 named storms, 2 cyclones, and 1 severe tropical cyclone. The season began with the formation of Tropical Storm Riley in January and ended with the dissipation of Severe Tropical Cyclone Owen in June.

### July - December

The 2023 Australian region cyclone season was above-average, with 8 named storms, 4 cyclones, and 2 severe tropical cyclones. The season began with the formation of Tropical Storm Liua in July and ended with the dissipation of Severe Tropical Cyclone Penny in December. The most notable storm of the season was Severe Tropical Cyclone Trevor, which made landfall in Northern Territory as a Category 4-equivalent severe tropical cyclone, causing significant damage and flooding.

## South Pacific Ocean

### January - June

The 2023 South Pacific Ocean cyclone season was near-average, with 5 named storms, 2 cyclones, and 1 severe tropical cyclone. The season began with the formation of Tropical Storm Fehi in January and ended with the dissipation of Severe Tropical Cyclone Gita in June.

### July - December

The 2023 South Pacific Ocean cyclone season was above-average, with 8 named storms, 4 cyclones, and 2 severe tropical cyclones. The season began with the formation of Tropical Storm Keni in July and ended with the dissipation of Severe Tropical Cyclone Oma in December. The most notable storm of the season was Severe Tropical Cyclone Pola, which made landfall in Tonga as a Category 4-equivalent severe tropical cyclone, causing significant damage and flooding.

## South Atlantic Ocean

The 2023 South Atlantic Ocean cyclone season was below-average, with only 1 named storm, Tropical Storm Iba, which formed in March and dissipated in April.

## Mediterranean Sea

The 2023 Mediterranean Sea cyclone season was near-average, with 2 named storms, Cyclone Cleopatra and Cyclone Daniel, which formed in October and November, respectively.

Starship Flight Test 1

The Starship Flight Test 1 was a crucial milestone in the development of SpaceX's Starship program, a next-generation reusable spacecraft designed for long-duration missions to the Moon, Mars, and other destinations in the solar system. The test aimed to demonstrate the vehicle's capabilities and gather valuable data for future improvements. This article provides an overview of the background, launch, and aftermath of the Starship Flight Test 1.

# Background

## Starship

Starship is a reusable spacecraft developed by SpaceX, a private aerospace manufacturer and space transport services company founded by Elon Musk. The vehicle is designed to be capable of carrying both crew and cargo on long-duration missions to the Moon, Mars, and other destinations in the solar system. Starship is a key component of SpaceX's ambitious plans to establish a permanent, self-sustaining human presence on Mars and to make humanity a multiplanetary species.

## Development

The development of Starship has been ongoing since 2016, with SpaceX investing significant resources in the program. The company has conducted numerous tests and demonstrations of the vehicle's components, including the Raptor engine, which is designed to power the Starship. In 2020, SpaceX began constructing the first Starship prototype, which was initially intended to be used for a series of suborbital test flights.

## Opinions before launch

In the lead-up to the Starship Flight Test 1, opinions about the test's prospects were divided. Some experts expressed concerns about the vehicle's design and the risks associated with the test, while others were more optimistic about the potential for success. Elon Musk, SpaceX's CEO, was characteristically confident about the test's chances, tweeting that the company was "hoping for a good test" but also emphasizing the importance of learning from failure.

## Test objectives

The primary objective of the Starship Flight Test 1 was to demonstrate the vehicle's ability to lift off from the launchpad, ascend to an altitude of approximately 8 kilometers (5 miles), and then return to Earth, landing safely back at the launch site. The test also aimed to gather data on the vehicle's performance, including its acceleration, deceleration, and navigation systems.

# Launch

## Flight profile

The Starship Flight Test 1 followed a suborbital flight profile, which involved lifting off from the launchpad, ascending to a maximum altitude of approximately 8 kilometers (5 miles), and then returning to Earth. The vehicle was not intended to reach orbit, but rather to demonstrate its ability to lift off and land safely.

## Flight timeline

The Starship Flight Test 1 was originally scheduled to take place on April 17, 2023. However, due to unfavorable weather conditions, the test was postponed to April 20, 2023. On the day of the test, the vehicle lifted off from the launchpad at SpaceX's Starbase facility in Boca Chica, Texas, at 8:00 AM CDT (13:00 UTC).

## April 17, 2023 attempt

The initial attempt to launch the Starship Flight Test 1 on April 17, 2023, was scrubbed due to unfavorable weather conditions. Strong winds and thunderstorms in the area made it unsafe to proceed with the test.

## April 20, 2023, 2nd attempt

The second attempt to launch the Starship Flight Test 1 on April 20, 2023, was successful. The vehicle lifted off from the launchpad at 8:00 AM CDT (13:00 UTC) and ascended to an altitude of approximately 8 kilometers (5 miles). However, the test did not go as planned, and the vehicle experienced a number of issues during the flight.

# Aftermath

## Technical assessments

Following the Starship Flight Test 1, SpaceX conducted a thorough technical assessment of the vehicle's performance. The company identified a number of issues that contributed to the test's outcome, including problems with the vehicle's navigation system and its ability to maintain control during the flight.

## Launch site

The Starship Flight Test 1 was launched from SpaceX's Starbase facility in Boca Chica, Texas. The facility has been the site of numerous tests and demonstrations of the Starship vehicle, and it is expected to play a key role in the development of the program.

## Effects on environment

The Starship Flight Test 1 had a number of effects on the environment, including the creation of a large plume of smoke and debris that was visible from a distance. The test also generated a significant amount of noise, which was heard by residents in the surrounding area.

## FAA investigation

Following the Starship Flight Test 1, the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) launched an investigation into the test's outcome. The agency is responsible for regulating the commercial space industry, and it is working to ensure that SpaceX and other companies comply with safety regulations.
