article:
Operation Gideon (2020)

Operation Gideon was a failed military incursion attempt into Venezuela, which took place on May 3, 2020. The operation aimed to overthrow the government of President Nicolás Maduro and replace it with an interim government led by Juan Guaidó, who was recognized as the legitimate president of Venezuela by many countries, including the United States. The operation was carried out by a group of Venezuelan ex-soldiers and American private military contractors, led by Jordan Goudreau, a former Green Beret.

#Background

In 2019, Venezuela was facing a severe economic and humanitarian crisis, which led to widespread protests and calls for Maduro's resignation. In January 2019, Juan Guaidó, the leader of the opposition-controlled National Assembly, declared himself interim president of Venezuela, citing the country's constitution. Guaidó's claim was recognized by many countries, including the United States, which imposed sanctions on Maduro's government.

#Planning

##Initial promotion: March–May 2019

In March 2019, Jordan Goudreau, a former Green Beret, began promoting a plan to overthrow Maduro's government through social media and interviews with journalists. Goudreau claimed that he had the support of Guaidó and other opposition leaders, although this was later denied.

##Colombia Silvercorp established: June 2019

In June 2019, Goudreau established a private military company called Silvercorp USA, which was based in Colombia. Silvercorp recruited a group of Venezuelan ex-soldiers and American private military contractors, who were trained in Colombia.

##Negotiations with Guaidó representatives: August–November 2019

In August 2019, Goudreau met with representatives of Guaidó's administration, including his chief of staff, Roberto Marrero. Goudreau proposed a plan to overthrow Maduro's government, which involved a military incursion into Venezuela. Marrero reportedly expressed interest in the plan, although Guaidó later denied any involvement.

##Alcalá and Goudreau resume preparations: December 2019

In December 2019, Clíver Alcalá, a former Venezuelan general, began working with Goudreau to resume preparations for the operation. Alcalá had been living in exile in Colombia and had been in contact with Goudreau since 2019.

##Extradition of Alcalá to the United States: March 2020

In March 2020, Alcalá was extradited to the United States, where he was charged with narcotics trafficking. Goudreau claimed that Alcalá's extradition was a setback for the operation, although he continued to plan the incursion.

###Prior knowledge of operation

It is unclear how much prior knowledge the Guaidó administration and other opposition leaders had of the operation. Guaidó later denied any involvement, although some of his representatives reportedly met with Goudreau and Alcalá.

##Final preparations, Associated Press article: April–May 2020

In April 2020, the Associated Press published an article about Goudreau's plan to overthrow Maduro's government. The article cited sources close to the operation and reported that Goudreau had recruited a group of Venezuelan ex-soldiers and American private military contractors.

#Landing attempt

On May 3, 2020, a group of eight men, including two American private military contractors, attempted to land on the coast of Venezuela near the port city of La Guaira. The men were armed and wore uniforms with the insignia of the Venezuelan military. The landing attempt was quickly thwarted by Venezuelan security forces, who killed six of the men and captured two others.

#Aftermath

##Indictments and arrests

In the aftermath of the landing attempt, several people were indicted and arrested in connection with the operation. In the United States, Goudreau was charged with conspiracy and weapons trafficking. In Venezuela, several people were arrested and charged with treason and terrorism.

##Criminal charges, extradition requests and sentences

Goudreau was charged with conspiracy and weapons trafficking in the United States. He pleaded not guilty and was released on bail. In Venezuela, several people were sentenced to prison terms for their role in the operation.

##Investigation of interception and deaths

Venezuela's government launched an investigation into the interception and deaths of the men who attempted to land on the coast. The investigation found that the men were armed and had planned to overthrow Maduro's government.

##Goudreau lawsuit

In 2020, Goudreau filed a lawsuit against the Venezuelan government, claiming that he had been the victim of a "setup" and that the operation had been planned and carried out by Venezuelan security forces.

#Reactions

##Domestic

###Maduro administration

Maduro's government condemned the landing attempt as a "terrorist attack" and accused the United States and other countries of supporting the operation.

###Guaidó administration and opposition

Guaidó's administration denied any involvement in the operation, although some opposition leaders expressed support for the attempt to overthrow Maduro's government.

###NGOs

Several non-governmental organizations (NGOs) condemned the landing attempt and expressed concern about the humanitarian situation in Venezuela.

##International

The international community was divided in its response to the landing attempt. The United States and other countries that recognize Guaidó as the legitimate president of Venezuela expressed support for the attempt to overthrow Maduro's government. Other countries, including Russia and China, condemned the operation and expressed support for Maduro's government.

##Characterization

The landing attempt was characterized as a "failed military incursion" and a "terrorist attack" by Maduro's government. Guaidó's administration and other opposition leaders characterized the attempt as a "coup" and a "desperate measure" to overthrow Maduro's government.

#In popular culture

The landing attempt was the subject of several news articles and documentaries. The operation was also the subject of a book, "The Venezuelan Coup: A Story of Oil, Guns and Money", which was published in 2020.

Far-right politics in Serbia
==========================

Introduction
------------

Far-right politics have a long and complex history in Serbia, dating back to the interwar period. The far-right ideology has evolved over time, influenced by various factors, including nationalism, anti-communism, and xenophobia. This article provides an overview of the definition, symbolism, influence, history, and contemporary manifestations of far-right politics in Serbia.

Overview
--------

### Definition

Far-right politics in Serbia are characterized by a strong nationalist and authoritarian ideology, often accompanied by xenophobic and anti-democratic sentiments. The far-right movement in Serbia encompasses a range of groups and individuals who advocate for a more centralized and authoritarian state, often at the expense of minority rights and democratic institutions.

### Symbolism

The far-right movement in Serbia often employs symbols and imagery associated with Serbian nationalism, such as the double-headed eagle, the Serbian cross, and the flag of Serbia. These symbols are often used to evoke a sense of national pride and unity, but can also be interpreted as exclusionary and divisive.

### Influence

Far-right politics have had a significant influence on Serbian society and politics, particularly during times of crisis and instability. The far-right movement has been able to mobilize significant support and resources, often through the use of social media and other online platforms. However, the influence of far-right politics has also been criticized for promoting intolerance, xenophobia, and violence.

History
-------

The far-right movement in Serbia has its roots in the interwar period, when nationalist and fascist movements were on the rise across Europe. During World War II, Serbia was occupied by Axis powers, and the far-right movement was suppressed. However, in the post-war period, the far-right ideology continued to evolve, often in opposition to the communist regime of Josip Broz Tito.

### 1990s–2000s

The far-right movement played a significant role in promoting Serbian nationalism and militarism, often through the use of propaganda and disinformation. However, the far-right movement was also criticized for promoting hatred and violence against minority groups, particularly Bosniaks and Croats.

article:
2022 Fukushima Earthquake

On March 16, 2022, a powerful earthquake struck the Fukushima Prefecture in Japan, causing widespread damage and triggering a tsunami warning. The earthquake, which had a magnitude of 7.4 on the moment magnitude scale, was centered off the coast of Fukushima and was felt as far away as Tokyo.

# Tectonic Setting

The 2022 Fukushima earthquake occurred in a region of complex tectonic activity, where the Pacific Plate is being subducted beneath the North American Plate. This process, known as subduction, is responsible for the formation of the Japan Trench, a deep-sea trench that runs along the eastern coast of Japan. The subduction of the Pacific Plate has resulted in the formation of a chain of volcanoes, including the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant, which was severely damaged in the 2011 Tohoku earthquake and tsunami.

# Earthquake

The 2022 Fukushima earthquake was a megathrust earthquake, which occurs when one tectonic plate is forced beneath another. The earthquake was characterized by a shallow focal depth, with the epicenter located approximately 50 kilometers off the coast of Fukushima. The earthquake's magnitude was measured at 7.4 on the moment magnitude scale, making it a major earthquake.

## Intensity

The intensity of the earthquake varied across the affected region, with the highest intensities reported in the coastal areas of Fukushima. The Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) reported that the earthquake had a maximum intensity of 6+ on the JMA seismic intensity scale, which is equivalent to a Mercalli intensity of VIII (Severe). The strong shaking caused widespread damage to buildings, roads, and other infrastructure.

## Long Period Ground Motion

The earthquake also generated long period ground motion, which is a type of seismic wave that can cause damage to tall buildings and other structures. The long period ground motion was particularly pronounced in the Tokyo region, where several buildings were evacuated as a precautionary measure.

# Tsunami

The earthquake triggered a tsunami warning, which was issued by the JMA for several coastal regions in eastern Japan. The tsunami warning was later downgraded to a tsunami advisory, but not before a small tsunami wave was reported in some areas. # Rule changes

The NCAA introduced several rule changes for the 2021–22 season. One of the most notable changes was the implementation of a 22-foot, 1.75-inch three-point line, which was previously 22 feet, 1.5 inches. This change aimed to increase spacing on the court and promote more outside shooting. 2023 North Indian Ocean cyclone season

The 2023 North Indian Ocean cyclone season is an ongoing event in the annual cycle of tropical cyclone formation in the North Indian Ocean. The season officially began on April 1, 2023, and will end on December 31, 2023. The North Indian Ocean cyclone season is a period of the year when most tropical cyclones form in the North Indian Ocean, which is bounded by India, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, and Southeast Asia.

# Season summary

The 2023 North Indian Ocean cyclone season has been an active season so far, with several cyclones forming in the Bay of Bengal and the Arabian Sea. The season began with the formation of Depression BOB 01 in May, which was followed by Extremely Severe Cyclonic Storm Mocha in June. July saw the formation of Extremely Severe Cyclonic Storm Biparjoy, which brought severe weather conditions to the coastal regions of India and Bangladesh. August and September saw the formation of several other cyclones, including Deep Depression BOB 03, Depression ARB 02, and Extremely Severe Cyclonic Storm Tej. The season is expected to continue until December 31, 2023, with the possibility of more cyclones forming in the coming months.

Depression BOB 01 was the first cyclone of the 2023 North Indian Ocean cyclone season. It formed on May 10, 2023, in the Bay of Bengal, approximately 450 km (280 miles) east-southeast of Visakhapatnam, India. The depression moved northwards and made landfall in Odisha, India, on May 12, 2023. Deep Depression BOB 03 was the fourth cyclone of the 2023 North Indian Ocean cyclone season. The cyclone brought severe weather conditions to the coastal regions of India and Bangladesh, causing widespread damage and flooding.

Very Severe Cyclonic Storm Hamoon was the seventh cyclone of the 2023 North Indian Ocean cyclone season. Severe Cyclonic Storm Midhili was the eighth cyclone of the 2023 North Indian Ocean cyclone season. article:
Indiewood
=========

Indiewood is a term used to describe the intersection of independent filmmaking and Hollywood. It refers to the blending of the creative freedom and innovative spirit of independent cinema with the financial resources and distribution networks of major Hollywood studios. This phenomenon has given rise to a new breed of filmmakers who are able to produce high-quality, critically acclaimed films that appeal to a wide audience.

Background
----------

The concept of Indiewood emerged in the 1990s, as the independent film movement gained momentum. Filmmakers like Steven Soderbergh, Quentin Tarantino, and Kevin Smith were able to make low-budget films that were both critically acclaimed and commercially successful. These films often premiered at film festivals, such as Sundance, and were later picked up by major studios for wider distribution.

As the independent film movement grew, major studios began to take notice. They saw the potential for low-budget films to generate high returns, and started to invest in independent productions. This led to the creation of "mini-major" studios, which were subsidiaries of major studios that focused on producing and distributing independent films.

Divisions
----------

Indiewood can be divided into several subcategories, each with its own distinct characteristics. These include:

* Low-budget films: These are films made on a limited budget, often with a small crew and minimal special effects. Examples include films like "Clerks" and "El Mariachi".
* Mid-budget films: These are films made on a moderate budget, often with a larger crew and more elaborate special effects. Examples include films like "Pulp Fiction" and "Reservoir Dogs".
* High-concept films: These are films with a unique concept or premise, often with a larger budget and more elaborate special effects. Examples include films like "The Matrix" and "Inception".

Other "mini-major" subdivisions/indie distributors
------------------------------------------------

In addition to the major studios, there are several other companies that specialize in producing and distributing independent films. These include:

* Miramax Films: Founded by Harvey and Bob Weinstein, Miramax is one of the most successful independent film distributors in history. They have released films like "Pulp Fiction", "The English Patient", and "Chicago".
* New Line Cinema: Founded in 1967, New Line Cinema is a subsidiary of Warner Bros. that specializes in producing and distributing independent films. They have released films like "The Lord of the Rings" trilogy and "The Conjuring".
* A24: Founded in 2012, A24 is a film production company and distributor that specializes in releasing independent films. They have released films like "Moonlight", "Lady Bird", and "The Witch".

Sources
--------

The term "Indiewood" was first coined by film critic and historian, John Pierson, in his 1995 book "Spike, Mike, Slackers & Dykes: A Guided Tour Across a Decade of American Independent Cinema".

Differences from Hollywood
---------------------------

Indiewood differs from traditional Hollywood in several key ways. These include:

* Budget: Indiewood films are often made on a much lower budget than traditional Hollywood films.
* Creative control: Indiewood filmmakers often have more creative control over their projects, as they are not beholden to the same commercial pressures as major studios.
* Distribution: Indiewood films are often released through smaller, independent distributors, rather than major studios.

article:
Russian information war against Ukraine

The Russian information war against Ukraine refers to the extensive use of propaganda, disinformation, and other forms of information warfare by Russia against Ukraine, particularly since the 2014 Ukrainian revolution. This information war is a key component of Russia's overall strategy to exert influence over Ukraine and undermine its sovereignty.

# Background

## Doctrine

Russia's information warfare doctrine is based on the concept of "information confrontation," which involves the use of information as a tool to achieve strategic objectives. This doctrine emphasizes the importance of shaping public opinion, both domestically and internationally, to support Russian interests. Russia's information warfare efforts are often characterized by a blurring of the lines between fact and fiction, as well as a reliance on conspiracy theories and misinformation.

## Reasons for the conflict

### Revanchism

One of the primary drivers of Russia's information war against Ukraine is a desire to reassert Russian influence over Ukraine and to challenge Ukraine's sovereignty. This desire is rooted in a sense of revanchism, or a desire to reclaim lost territory and influence. Russia has long considered Ukraine to be within its sphere of influence, and the 2014 Ukrainian revolution was seen as a challenge to this influence.

### History of the war

The Russian information war against Ukraine began in earnest in 2014, following the Ukrainian revolution. Russia responded to the revolution by launching a propaganda campaign aimed at discrediting the new Ukrainian government and promoting a pro-Russian agenda. This campaign included the use of state-controlled media outlets, as well as social media and other online platforms. Russia also began to support separatist groups in eastern Ukraine, which led to the outbreak of conflict in the region.

# Information operations

## Censorship

Russia has used censorship as a key tool in its information war against Ukraine. This has included the blocking of Ukrainian news websites and social media platforms, as well as the censorship of Russian-language media outlets that have been critical of the Kremlin. Russia has also used its control over the internet infrastructure in eastern Ukraine to limit access to information and to promote pro-Russian propaganda.

## Telecommunications

Russia has also used its control over telecommunications networks in eastern Ukraine to disrupt communication between Ukraine and the outside world. This has included the jamming of mobile phone signals and the disruption of internet connectivity.

## Internet infrastructure

Russia has sought to exert control over the internet infrastructure in Ukraine, including the country's domain name system (DNS). This has allowed Russia to block access to Ukrainian websites and to promote pro-Russian propaganda.

## War propaganda

Russia has used war propaganda as a key tool in its information war against Ukraine. This has included the promotion of conspiracy theories and misinformation about Ukraine and its government. Russia has also sought to promote a pro-Russian agenda through the use of patriotic and nationalist rhetoric.

## Control of news outlets

### Public relations

Russia has used public relations firms to promote its interests and to shape public opinion. This has included the use of PR firms to promote pro-Russian propaganda and to discredit Ukrainian government officials.

### Ukraine

Russia has sought to exert control over Ukrainian news outlets, including through the use of propaganda and disinformation. Russia has also used its influence over Ukrainian media outlets to promote a pro-Russian agenda.

### Russia

#### RT

Russia's state-controlled news outlet, RT (formerly Russia Today), has played a key role in promoting pro-Russian propaganda and disinformation. RT has been used to promote conspiracy theories and misinformation about Ukraine and its government.

### Russian interference with Ukrainian media

Russia has interfered with Ukrainian media outlets, including through the use of hacking and other forms of cyber warfare. Russia has also used its influence over Ukrainian media outlets to promote a pro-Russian agenda.

## Methods and resources

### Disinformation

Russia has used disinformation as a key tool in its information war against Ukraine. This has included the promotion of conspiracy theories and misinformation about Ukraine and its government.

#### Falsehoods and adamant denials

Russia has used falsehoods and adamant denials to promote its interests and to shape public opinion. This has included the denial of Russian involvement in the conflict in eastern Ukraine, despite overwhelming evidence to the contrary.

##### 2014

In 2014, Russia denied any involvement in the conflict in eastern Ukraine, despite evidence of Russian military involvement.

##### Malaysia Airlines Flight 17

In 2014, Russia denied any involvement in the downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17, despite evidence of Russian military involvement.

##### 2022

In 2022, Russia denied any involvement in the conflict in eastern Ukraine, despite evidence of Russian military involvement.

### Tropes

Russia has used tropes, or common themes and motifs, to promote its interests and to shape public opinion. This has included the use of patriotic and nationalist rhetoric to promote a pro-Russian agenda.

### Social media

Russia has used social media as a key tool in its information war against Ukraine. This has included the use of social media platforms to promote pro-Russian propaganda and disinformation.

#### Access to social media

Russia has sought to limit access to social media in eastern Ukraine, including through the use of censorship and other forms of control.

#### Attempts to censor Russian Wikipedia

Russia has attempted to censor Russian-language Wikipedia, including through the use of blocking and other forms of control.

# Timeline

## 2014

### January

In January 2014, Russia began to promote a pro-Russian agenda in Ukraine, including through the use of propaganda and disinformation.

### February

In February 2014, Russia supported the ousting of Ukrainian President Viktor Yanukovych, who was seen as a pro-Russian leader.

### March

In March 2014, Russia annexed Crimea, which was widely seen as a challenge to Ukraine's sovereignty.

### April

In April 2014, Russia began to support separatist groups in eastern Ukraine, which led to the outbreak of conflict in the region.

### May

In May 2014, Russia promoted a pro-Russian agenda in eastern Ukraine, including through the use of propaganda and disinformation.

### June

In June 2014, Russia continued to support separatist groups in eastern Ukraine, despite international pressure to stop.

### July-August

In July and August 2014, Russia's support for separatist groups in eastern Ukraine led to the downing of Malaysia Airlines Flight 17.

### October

In October 2014, Russia continued to promote a pro-Russian agenda in Ukraine, including through the use of propaganda and disinformation.

### December

In December 2014, Russia's support for separatist groups in eastern Ukraine led to the outbreak of conflict in the region.

## 2015

### January

In January 2015, Russia continued to promote a pro-Russian agenda in Ukraine, including through the use of propaganda and disinformation.

### February

In February 2015, Russia supported the Minsk II agreement, which aimed to bring an end to the conflict in eastern Ukraine.

### March

In March 2015, Russia continued to support separatist groups in eastern Ukraine, despite international pressure to stop.

### June

In June 2015, Russia promoted a pro-Russian agenda in eastern Ukraine, including through the use of propaganda and disinformation.

## 2016

In 2016, Russia continued to promote a pro-Russian agenda in Ukraine, including through the use of propaganda and disinformation.

## 2017

In 2017, Russia continued to support separatist groups in eastern Ukraine, despite international pressure to stop.

## 2018

In 2018, Russia promoted a pro-Russian agenda in Ukraine, including through the use of propaganda and disinformation.

## 2019

In 2019, Russia continued to support separatist groups in eastern Ukraine, despite international pressure to stop.

## 2021

In 2021, Russia promoted a pro-Russian agenda in Ukraine, including through the use of propaganda and disinformation.

## 2022

### January

In January 2022, Russia continued to promote a pro-Russian agenda in Ukraine, including through the use of propaganda and disinformation.

### February

In February 2022, Russia launched a large-scale invasion of Ukraine, which was widely seen as a challenge to Ukraine's sovereignty.

### March

In March 2022, Russia continued to support separatist groups in eastern Ukraine, despite international pressure to stop.

# Staged videos

Russia has used staged videos to promote its interests and to shape public opinion. This has included the use of fake videos to promote conspiracy theories and misinformation about Ukraine and its government.

# Results

The Russian information war against Ukraine has had a significant impact on the country and its people. This has included the promotion of a pro-Russian agenda, the spread of conspiracy theories and misinformation, and the undermining of Ukraine's sovereignty.

# Countermeasures

## Zelenskyy

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy has taken steps to counter Russia's information war, including the use of social media to promote a pro-Ukrainian agenda.

### Propaganda in other countries

Ukraine has also sought to counter Russia's propaganda efforts in other countries, including through the use of public diplomacy and other forms of outreach.

## Memes

Ukraine has used memes to promote a pro-Ukrainian agenda and to counter Russia's propaganda efforts. This has included the use of social media platforms to promote memes and other forms of humor.

John Hoogenakker
================

John Hoogenakker is an American actor known for his versatility and range in various stage, television, and film productions. With a career spanning over two decades, Hoogenakker has established himself as a talented and dedicated actor, taking on a wide range of roles in different genres.

Early Life and Education
------------------------

John Hoogenakker was born on June 9, 1977, in Omaha, Nebraska. Growing up in a family of artists, Hoogenakker was exposed to the world of performing arts from a young age. His parents, both music teachers, encouraged his passion for acting and supported his decision to pursue a career in the entertainment industry.

Hoogenakker attended the University of Nebraska at Omaha, where he earned a Bachelor of Fine Arts degree in acting. During his time at college, he was actively involved in various stage productions, honing his craft and developing his skills as a performer.

Career
--------

### Stage Work

Hoogenakker's professional career began in the early 2000s, when he started performing in various stage productions in the Chicago area. He worked with several theater companies, including the Steppenwolf Theatre Company and the Goodman Theatre, taking on roles in plays such as "The Crucible" and "The Glass Menagerie."

In 2008, Hoogenakker made his Broadway debut in the play "The Seagull," directed by Ian Rickson. His performance as Konstantin Treplev earned him critical acclaim and recognition within the theater community.

### Television and Film Work

Hoogenakker's transition to television and film began in the mid-2000s, with guest appearances in TV shows such as "ER" and "Chicago Fire." He also landed roles in several independent films, including "The Post" and "Warrior."

In 2013, Hoogenakker was cast in the HBO series "The Newsroom," created by Aaron Sorkin. His portrayal of a young reporter earned him praise from critics and audiences alike.

Hoogenakker's breakthrough role came in 2019, when he was cast as a series regular in the CBS drama "Tommy." His performance as a detective earned him critical acclaim and a nomination for a Critics' Choice Television Award.

Personal Life
-------------

Hoogenakker is married to actress and writer, Elizabeth Hoogenakker. The couple met while working on a stage production in Chicago and have been together ever since.

Hoogenakker is also an avid music lover and plays the guitar in his free time. He has been involved in several charity organizations, including the American Cancer Society and the Alzheimer's Association.
